Introduction

A urethral diverticulum is a localized outpouching of the urethral mucosa through the muscular wall of the urethra.  It predominantly affects women and typically presents with dysuria, postvoid dribbling, dyspareunia, and an anterior vaginal wall mass.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



The exact pathogenesis of a urethral diverticulum is not entirely understood, but it likely arises from recurrent periurethral gland infections, which can develop into an abscess that eventually breaches the urethral mucosa.  The persistent infection, inflammation, and increased tissue tension in the area can cause development of the diverticulum and a tender anterior vaginal wall mass.  The diverticulum may collect urine and debris, resulting in purulent discharge, dysuria, or postvoid dribbling.



Other possible causes include recurrent urinary tract infections (because chronic inflammation can weaken the urethral wall), pelvic floor trauma or surgery (eg, vaginal delivery), and recurrent obstruction (eg, urethral stone).

Clinical presentation



Patients with a urethral diverticulum (

figure 1
) may have a range of symptoms, but the classic triad of symptoms includes:



  • Dysuria
  • Dyspareunia
  • Postvoid dribbling (due to urine trapping in the diverticulum)


Other symptoms include recurrent urinary tract infection, urinary incontinence, and a palpable, tender mass in the anterior vaginal wall with or without a purulent, bloody discharge.

Diagnosis, laboratory evaluation, and imaging



Diagnosis of a urethral diverticulum is confirmed with pelvic MRI (gold standard) in patients suspected of having urethral diverticulum.  Prior to imaging, other etiologies for the clinical presentation should be excluded by performing the following:



  • Physical examination:  Most urethral diverticula form on the posterior aspect of the urethra, which can be felt as a tender, anterior vaginal wall mass.  When the diverticulum is palpated, a purulent or bloody discharge may be expressed through the urethra.
  • Urinalysis:  used to evaluate for malignancy and urinary tract infection.  Patients with a urethral diverticulum can have leukocytes and blood on urinalysis (due to inflammation and collection of debris).  Those with a positive urinalysis require urine culture.
  • Urine culture:  performed to rule out urinary tract infection.

Differential diagnosis



Several conditions may mimic urethral diverticula, including:



  • Urinary tract infections:  can present with dysuria, incontinence, and postvoid dribbling, but patients do not have an anterior vaginal wall mass.
  • Cystocele (anterior vaginal wall prolapse):  often presents with vaginal pressure and incomplete bladder emptying (due to loss of anterior vaginal wall support).  Patients have a large vaginal mass (due to herniation of bladder into vagina) that increases with the Valsalva maneuver, not a discrete tender mass that produces purulent fluid through the urethra with palpation.
  • Interstitial cystitis:  typically presents with pain with bladder filling that is relieved by voiding.  There is typically no postvoid dribbling or anterior vaginal wall mass.
  • Urethral stricture:  narrowing of the urethra; can cause dysuria, dyspareunia, and recurrent urinary tract infections, but patients typically do not have an anterior vaginal wall mass.
  • Vesicovaginal fistula (
    figure 2
    ):  typically presents with constant, rather than intermittent, leakage of urine due to continuous drainage of the bladder into the vagina.  In addition, there is no associated anterior vaginal wall mass.

Management



In patients who are asymptomatic or have mild symptoms, management is conservative, with antibiotic prophylaxis against urinary tract infections.  In most cases, however, treatment is surgical with removal of the diverticulum (diverticulectomy).

Prognosis



The prognosis for patients with a urethral diverticulum is generally favorable, especially with appropriate surgical intervention.  Recurrence rates are low, but patients should be monitored for potential complications, including urethral stricture formation, urinary incontinence, and recurrent urinary tract infections.
